messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] umegane-good or bad?
messages.msgSnippet: Ahh, the good old days. Gordon ... From: MuramasaIII@aol.com [mailto:MuramasaIII@aol.com] Sent: Tuesday, July 08, 2003 8:52 AM To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
messages.messageBody:
Ahh, the good old days.

Gordon
-----Original Message-----
From: MuramasaIII@... [mailto:MuramasaIII@...]
Sent: Tuesday, July 08, 2003 8:52 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] umegane-good or bad?


In a message dated 7/7/2003 6:28:46 PM Central Daylight Time,
robsongo@... writes:

> Hi Peter,
>
> Not really sure about that. I would expect late Edo or so and I am sure
they
> must have been a cheap fix. I do not know how much the umegane work on
my
> own sword will run, but I was told it was expensive.
>
> Gordon
>

Gordon, Pete und all,
According to Inami Hakusui in his book " Nippon-to, the Japanese Sword "
published in 1948 , the cost of sword polish done in Japan " is about
four
dollars " < page 102 >.

So the cost of umegane cannot be that much more ( at that time, i.e. )?

Milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] umegane-good or bad?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Peter, Not really sure about that. I would expect late Edo or so and I am sure they must have been a cheap fix. I do not know how much the umegane work on
messages.messageBody:
Hi Peter,

Not really sure about that. I would expect late Edo or so and I am sure they
must have been a cheap fix. I do not know how much the umegane work on my
own sword will run, but I was told it was expensive.

Gordon
-----Original Message-----
From: Peter A Bleed [mailto:pbleed1@...]
Sent: Monday, July 07, 2003 11:41 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] umegane-good or bad?



Gordon, Thanks for the insightful comments. They were very useful. Doesn't
anyone happen to know when umegane were developed. I assume that they
would
be an expensive fix these days, but in the days of cheap labor, like say
the Edo period, might they have been a cheap fix?

Peter Bleed
Associate Dean
College of Arts and Sciences
1223 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0312
(402) 472-2891


Hi Peter,

I don't know if this has been answered yet, but, in general umegane are
always bad, particularly if they are easy to spot. In a blade like this
Fujishima where open, flowing grain in the shinogi-ji is to be expected,
doing an umegane is just silly. The same is true with a very fine omi-yari
I
own that is hugh. It also has a series of rectangular umegane that have
mostly fallen out. The blade is Kanabo and one should expect powerful
running masame that opens up in places in such a work. There is no reason
to
do umegane and now that they are visible and have fallen out, it detracts
a
great deal from the blade. On the other had, I have a rather nice katana
where the umegane had fallen out. I had it replaced. You can't see it and
it
looks better now as opposed to the open hole in the skin. So, a case by
case
answer. Just my 25 cents worth.

Gordon
-----Original Message-----
From: Peter A Bleed [mailto:pbleed1@...]
Sent: Friday, July 04, 2003 12:09 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] umegane-good or bad?



Listeros!
Allow me to once again present the limits of knowledge with a
question that others may find either 1) of interest or 2) answerable.
Yesterday I looked at a "sword" brought home from the Philippines
and
owned (proudly) by the nephew of the man who sent it home in 1944. Since
this could be anything and not likely for sale, I think we will all
agree
that the chances of this being of any interest were pretty slim.
Surprise,
it turned out to b a relatively clean wakizashi in a nice old
shira-saya.
The blade was signed Fujishima Tomoshige, I assume one of the late
koto/very early Shinto Kaga smiths of that line - tight itame with a
komidare. A sword.
Perhaps the most interesting thing about the sword was a
rectangular
umegane set into the shinogi-ji in the monouchi. It measured maybe 1/4"
by
1/2" and was clearly visible. It had not fully removed the flaw since
there
was a clear fukure on its edge.
My question to the List is whether on not this kind of umegane is
good or bad. Well, it can hardly be "good," right? There was a flaw
there,
but an umegane must be better than a flaw, right? Does an umegane
detract
from or enhance the value of a sword? And how visible should an umegane
be? Is the fact that this plug was clearly visible - and square! - mean
that it was poorly done?
Peter Bleed




Yahoo! Groups Sponsor

nihontostudy-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com



Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

messages.messageBody:
Gordon, Thanks for the insightful comments. They were very useful. Doesn't
anyone happen to know when umegane were developed. I assume that they would
be an expensive fix these days, but in the days of cheap labor, like say
the Edo period, might they have been a cheap fix?

Peter Bleed
Associate Dean
College of Arts and Sciences
1223 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0312
(402) 472-2891


Hi Peter,

I don't know if this has been answered yet, but, in general umegane are
always bad, particularly if they are easy to spot. In a blade like this
Fujishima where open, flowing grain in the shinogi-ji is to be expected,
doing an umegane is just silly. The same is true with a very fine omi-yari
I
own that is hugh. It also has a series of rectangular umegane that have
mostly fallen out. The blade is Kanabo and one should expect powerful
running masame that opens up in places in such a work. There is no reason
to
do umegane and now that they are visible and have fallen out, it detracts a
great deal from the blade. On the other had, I have a rather nice katana
where the umegane had fallen out. I had it replaced. You can't see it and
it
looks better now as opposed to the open hole in the skin. So, a case by
case
answer. Just my 25 cents worth.

Gordon
